courses.description: This internship is a professional learning experience that offers meaningful, practical work related to your field of study. You will undertake a 75-hour internship with an approved industry supervisor to demonstrate the application of your disciplinary and academic learning in real-world contexts and how it strengthens your knowledge, skills and attributes needed to contribute to and excel in your profession. Recognition of prior learning (RPL) is not available for this unit as you are required to demonstrate application of theory, knowledge, skills, and attributes from within your current degree and not from previous qualifications and/or work experience. You are permitted to undertake an internship with your existing employer provided it is a specified project or a new role that demonstrates the application of your current degree and not part of a previous award and/or your pre-existing day-to-day work activities. Approval of the project or role will be required by the Internship Unit Convenor. Students enrolled in a law degree must undertake an internship in an approved legal workplace. courses.name: Big Data and Marketing Analytics
courses.description: The unit will provide students with an understanding of the conceptual foundations of Big Data and Marketing Analytics. It will unpack important concepts and techniques such as data visualization, machine learning, statistical analysis, qualitative analysis, and data-driven marketing strategies. Furthermore, students will critically reflect on the ethical aspects of big data. Throughout the course, students will explore various types of big data, including data from websites, social media, and search engines, and focus on the 5Vs of big data: volume, velocity, variety, veracity, and value. This course will also provide students with hands-on experience with data analytics in a marketing setting. This unit will provide students with both theoretical underpinnings and real world practice, which will be applied to provide decision makers with current and future tools to increase their market share, ROI and how well the market and organisation are performing.
learning_outcomes: Explain the theory and practice of marketing analytics, and the practice of managing and studying metrics data to identify opportunities for improvement within organisations
Define the role of big data in contemporary marketing practices
Apply big data analysis tools to develop customer insight and undertake marketing decisions
Critically reflect on the ethical aspects of big data and marketing analytics including privacy and security
Apply automated technology and analytical processes to marketing-related data, and to create data drive marketing strategies.

courses.name: Business Decision Making
courses.description: Many university graduates aim to become managers, either of their own business, or as part of the management team of other entities. A critical attribute of management is the ability to incorporate financial and non-financial data in a range of decisions, such as pricing products, setting budgets, and evaluating performance. However, many decision makers have not studied accounting or information systems. This unit aims to address this gap by showing students how to identify, obtain, manipulate and analyse data to make informed business decisions. The nature of information used to inform decisions continues to change, in that big data, artificial intelligence or automation processes, alongside other competing data sources, may contribute to the information available to managers. Decision makers must be able to weigh up competing information sources, as well as their intuition, to make business decisions in an uncertain environment.
learning_outcomes: Apply cost classifications and cost behaviour to a range of decisions, including budgeting
Interpret the impact a range of transactions and events will have on financial reports
Develop spreadsheet models to support simple decision making in a variety of contexts
Apply a systems approach to facilitate decision making
Apply cost-benefit analysis concepts to various business decision making contexts
Evaluate the impact of different sources of information on business decisions and how those decisions impact on internal and external stakeholders.

courses.name: Consumer and Buyer Behaviour
courses.description: This unit covers both consumer behaviour and business buying behaviour. Students will explore the processes that consumers go through when selecting services and goods, such as the individual customer make up and environmental influences that impact on human decision making. Consumers' culture and social status, psychographics and demographic factors as well as the role of emotion and humour in marketing strategies will be discussed and analysed. Of equal importance is how businesses/organisations make purchasing decisions and students analyse how this is different/ similar to consumer decision making processes in new task buying and repeat buying decision making processes.
learning_outcomes: Identify and interpret consumer behaviour theory and its implications for marketing strategy in both consumer, organisational and industrial markets
Analyse consumer decision making processes in different scenarios
Evaluate consumer decision making theories and apply to new product development and entrepreneurial environments
Analyse how cultural differences impact on marketing strategies
Compare organisational buyer behaviour in different settings to consumer buying behaviour
Describe the scope and nature of psychology and sociology in consumer behaviour.

courses.name: Introduction to Economics
courses.description: Studying economics will give you a good understanding of current economic challenges and equip you with the essential technical skills and framework to address them. This unit will introduce you to basic concepts in microeconomics and macroeconomics and their application to real world phenomena. In the microeconomics part, you will study the behaviour of individual economic units (such as households and firms) in the market and how government policies affect them. You will also learn about key macroeconomic indicators such as inflation and unemployment and how macroeconomic policies can be used to achieve national economic objectives. You will develop an insight into the economic way of thinking and learn how economics can be used to analyse every day economic problems and inform policy.
learning_outcomes: Demonstrate how businesses can use economic models in their decision making
Identify the factors that affect the demand and supply for goods and services in the market and explain how changes in these factors affect the market equilibrium price and quantity
Analyse how government intervention in the market, for example through imposition of taxes or price ceilings, affect the behaviour of consumers and producers
Analyse efficient production decisions under different types of market structures and identify when and why markets fail to perform efficiently
Describe macroeconomic aggregates such as GDP, unemployment, and inflation and outline how government and central bank policies affect these variables
Review and communicate the outcome of economic research and analysis.

courses.name: Quantitative Methods
courses.description: This unit is designed to provide basic quantitative skills which are an essential foundation to decision-making and professional advice in a range of business situations. Upon completion of this unit students should be able to apply the quantitative tools presented so that they are able to analyse, understand, explain and evaluate data related to market events, government policies and business decision-making. The unit content includes working with equations and graphs of straight lines, linear programming, quantitative research principles in collecting, summarising and displaying business data, index numbers, relations in quantitative and categorical data, measures of association, regressions, elementary probability concepts, the normal distribution and its business applications. Students will carry out these techniques manually and/or through spreadsheets.
learning_outcomes: Solve a range of business problems using the relevant and appropriate quantitative tools
Clearly communicate the implications of the techniques applied in a range of business situations
Apply a range of quantitative techniques to solve problems in business, economics and finance
Explain how data is sampled, collected and presented using a range of summary measures
Select appropriate techniques in addressing unfamiliar problems in business, finance and economics
Apply forecasting methods in business, economics and finance.

courses.name: Small Business Management
courses.description: Small business is not small: it creates the most jobs and advances innovation in both developed and developing economies. In this unit, we co-develop you into entrepreneurs, managers, and innovators of small business. We introduce the fundamentals of small business management in both traditional and new sectors, as well as analyse the best practices of them in local, national, and international contexts. Further, we explore, stimulate, and incubate new small business thinking and ideas that are visionary and futuristic. We employ experiential and authentic teaching, learning, and engaging approaches to grow a new generation of business leaders. More importantly, we uncover and inspire the qualities and capabilities in you that will enable your success and resilience in a globalised business environment of increasing competition, disruption, and change.
learning_outcomes: Grasp the fundamentals of small business management
Analyse small business management cases to develop and apply best practices
Create new thinking and ideas for small business futures
Communicate small business ideas professionally.

courses.name: Social Marketing - Marketing for Good
courses.description: Social marketing is the application of commercial marketing principles to solve social problems for the good of people and planet. Social marketing is increasingly being adopted by government and non-profit organisations globally as a way of achieving the United Nation¿s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) (e.g. poverty, health, climate change, decent work). This unit introduces students to the theory and application of social marketing, explaining how techniques such as branding, segmentation, customer value and the marketing mix can be used to respond to social and environmental issues. Using problem-based learning, students will analyse real world problems and develop innovative and creative solutions using social marketing frameworks. The unit will use design-thinking to creatively ideate concepts and prototypes for the development of a social marketing program to address problems. Policy makers and industry managers are involved in this unit providing valuable real world connections between theory and practice.
learning_outcomes: Describe the key principles and concepts of social marketing and service design
Apply service design processes and social marketing theories to analyse real-world social and environmental problems in Australia
Create service design concepts and prototypes for a social marketing program that addresses real world problems
Evaluate the ethical issues around the implementation of social marketing service design campaigns and programs.
